Title: Having Fun With a Scamming Crypto Job
Description:
I‚Äôm going to cover what happened and the technical details of a crypto job scam that I‚Äôve avoided. Let‚Äôs hope that it can be both entertaining and informative.
It‚Äôs my second time encoutering this kind of scam. In the first time, I just ignored it as the sign is too obvious: a non-fitting job (frontend heavy job for a backend guy) where the recruiter is ‚Äúimpressed with my technical skills‚Äù and think that I‚Äôm ‚Äúan exellent fit‚Äù.

Title: Mastodon Exit Interview
Description: I am currently winding down the Mastodon bots I used to post sunrise and sunset times. The precipitating event is that the admin of the instance hosting the associated accounts demanded they be made nigh-undiscoverable, but the underlying cause is that it‚Äôs become increasing clear that Mastodon isn‚Äôt, and won‚Äôt ever be, a good platform for ‚Äúasynchronous ephemeral notifications of any kind‚Äù. I‚Äôd also argue (more controversially) that it‚Äôs simply not good infrastructure for social networking of any kind. There are lots of interesting people using Mastodon, and I‚Äôm sure it will live on as a good-enough space for certain niche groups. But there is no question that it will never offer the fun of early Twitter, let alone the vibrancy of Twitter during its growth phase. I‚Äôve long since dropped Mastodon from my home screen, and have switched to Bluesky for text-centric social media.

Title: Anachronym Challenge
The Secret To Planning An Impactful Conference Talk!
Description:
Ever sat through a conference talk wondering "Why should I care?" or "What's in it for me?" You're not alone. In this video, I'll reveal the secret that most speakers miss when planning their talks, and how you can avoid this common pitfall.

Hi, I'm James, a storytelling technologist who's delivered talks worldwide. I'm about to share the #1 most crucial principle that will transform your presentations from self-centered to audience-captivating.

What You'll Learn:
- The fundamental truth about who the REAL hero of your talk should be (hint: it's not you)
- Why even the most brilliant technical content fails without this key element
- How to instantly connect with your audience by addressing their specific pain points
- The difference between generic industry talk and compelling personal storytelling
- My proven template for planning audience-centered presentations

I'll demonstrate this principle through contrasting examples of conference openings and share a behind-the-scenes look at my own talk planning process.

üîó FREE DOWNLOAD: Get my conference talk planning template in the description below to start creating presentations that truly resonate with your audience. - https://speak.jameseastham.co.uk

Title: Boost ASP.NET Performance with Response Caching üî•
Description:
Speed up your ASP.NET Core applications and reduce server load with Response Caching! In this video, we break down what response caching is, why it's important, and how to use the [ResponseCache] attribute to control how your responses are cached on the client or by proxies.

You'll learn:
‚úÖThe real-world benefits of response caching üöÄ
‚úÖHow to use [ResponseCache] with Duration, Location
‚úÖHow to dynamically control caching based on user roles or headers
‚úÖBest practices and common pitfalls to avoid

Whether you're building APIs, MVC views, or high-traffic sites, caching is one of the easiest ways to gain massive performance wins.

üëâ Official Documentation:
üìò https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/performance/caching/response

Title: Mistakes and cool things to do with arena allocators
Description:
When programming in Odin you can use arena allocators. If you use an arena allocator combined with a dynamic array, then there are a couple of pitfalls that may not be apparent at first. Let‚Äôs look at what arenas are, how you can run into trouble when naively using them with dynamic arrays and what you can do instead.
What‚Äôs an arena? How does it work? Arenas and arena allocators are useful for grouping allocations that have the same lifetime.

Code that worked perfectly yesterday suddenly breaks today, and you‚Äôre not sure why. You keep switching between files and conversations, losing your flow. Title: Optimizing memory usage with modern .NET features
Description:
After my service migrated
from .NET Framework to .NET 8 (and later to .NET 9), it felt like a whole new world had opened to me. All
the modern .NET features that I had only been reading about on the .NET Blog
were finally available to me. Armed with Microsoft‚Äôs continuous, fleet-wide performance profiler, I embarked on a journey
to find the places where my service was allocating the most memory and fix the unnecessary allocations by using the newly
available .NET APIs. In this blog post, I‚Äôll show you some common code patterns that can be found in .NET Framework code,
along with their modern, high-performance alternatives.
